introduction.p: In general, a probability model is a pair (\Omega,P), where \Omega is a set, and where P is a function on a subset of the power set of \Omega. What all probability models have in common are the vocabulary () and properties () that you have already seen for finite probability models in the previous section. We begin with a generalization of the finite probability model.

subsection.title: Discrete Probability Models
subsection.p: The definitions (, , ) for a finite probability model generalize naturally for countably infinite probability spaces. The only necessary change is to replace the word finite with the phrase finite or countably infinite. Together, finite probability models and their countably infinite generalizations are called discrete probability models.

definition.p: A probability function on a finite or countably infinite set \Omega is a function p\colon \Omega\to [0,1] that satisfies \sum_{\omega\in\Omega}p(\omega)=1. A discrete probability measure on a finite or countably infinite space \Omega is a function P\colon \mathcal{P}(\Omega)\to [0,1] given by P(E)=\sum_{e\in E}p(e) for E\subseteq \Omega, where p is a probability function on \Omega. A discrete probability model is a pair (\Omega,P), where \Omega is a finite or countably infinite set, and where P is a discrete probability measure on \Omega.

subsection.p: Example. Let \Omega=\{1,2,3,\ldots\}, and let p\colon \Omega\to [0,1] given by p(n)=1/2^n.

ol.li: Show that p is a probability function.
Find the probability of the event E=\{1,2,3,\ldots, n\}.
Find the probability of the event F=\{5k\colon k=1,2,3,\ldots\}.

ol.li: Show that the function p_{\Omega^n} is indeed a probability function.
Do simple random samples make sense for infinite probability spaces?
The same derivation used in is valid here as well.
No. Simple random samples presume the existence of a constant probability function. This cannot exist for an infinite probability space.

subsection.title: Uncountable probability spaces
subsection.p: For an uncountable set \Omega, it is impossible to have a probability function. That is, there does not exist any function p\colon \Omega \to [0,1] that satisfies \sum_{\omega\in \Omega}p(\omega)=1. Nevertheless, it is possible to define a probability measure in a way that satisfies all of the properties in by restricting the set of events to a proper subset of the power set \mathcal{P}(\Omega). In these notes, we will omit the technical details for how this is done. Instead we will illustrate with two examples.

exercise.p: Why not? Why is it impossible to have a probability function on an uncountable set?

aside.title: Instructor solution for
aside.p: Let \Omega be an uncountable set, and let p\colon \Omega\to [0,1] be a function such that \sum_{\omega\in\Omega}p(\omega)=1. For each n=1,2,3\ldots, let S_n=\{\omega\in \Omega\colon p(\omega)\geq 1/n\}. We must have |S_n|\leq n. We have \{\omega\in\Omega\colon p(\omega)\gt 0\} = \bigcup_{k=1}^{\infty}S_n which is countable. This makes the notion of a probability function on an uncountable set superfluous, because any probability function can only be nonzero on a countable subset.

subsection.p: Uniform probability measures. Let \Omega be the set of points inside of a geometric figure with a finite area or volume, say, a two-dimensional figure with area equal to A square units. Given any rectangle R\subset\Omega, define P(R) to be P(R)=\frac{\text{area of }R}{A}. This probability measure is uniform in the sense that it doesn't matter where R is located with \Omega. The probability of R is completely determined by its area. Similarly, the uniform probability measure on an interval \Omega=[a,b] of real numbers is given by P([c,d]) = \frac{d-c}{b-a} for any interval [c,d]\subseteq \Omega.

Infinite sequences of coin tosses Let \Omega be the set of infinite sequences of tosses of a fair coin. For (\omega_1,\omega_2,\omega_3,\ldots)\in \Omega, each entry \omega_k is one of the two outcomes in the probability space C=\{H,T\} (C is for coin, H is for heads, and T is for tails) with probability function p(H)=p(T)=1/2. Now suppose that E\subseteq C^n, so that P_{C^n}(E)=|E|/2^n (see ). Let E' is the subset of \Omega defined by E'=\{(\omega_1,\omega_2,\omega_3,\ldots)\in \Omega\colon (\omega_1,\omega_2,\ldots,\omega_n)\in E\}. If it is possible to define a probability measure P_{\Omega}, then intuition demands that we must have P_{\Omega}(E')=P_{C^n}(E). In fact it turns out that such a probability measure exists. We will not give the full details for how it is constructed. Happily, it turns out that give us what we need to work with the probability space (\Omega,P_{\Omega}).

ol.li: Find the probability that the first head in an infinite sequence of tosses occurs on toss number 5.

Use Cantor's diagonal argument. Assume that \Omega is countable, with enumeration \omega_1,\omega_2,\ldots. Now construct a sequence r by r_k = H if (\omega_k)_k=T and r_k = T if (\omega_k)_k=H. It must be that r is not equal to any \omega_k, which is a contradiction.

subsection.p: Samples from uncountable probability models. For an uncountable probability model (\Omega,P), we define the probability space of samples of size n from \Omega to be the space \Omega^n with probability measure P_{\Omega^n} defined by P_{\Omega^n}(E_1\times E_2\times \cdots \times E_n) = P(E_1)P(E_2)\cdots P(E_n) where E_1,E_2,\ldots,E_n are events in \Omega.
